unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked if investing in the stock market is worth it. Well, from my experience, it's a definite "maybe," leaning towards "yes, but with caution." I started with a small amount, ₹5000, through a friend's recommendation on this app called "Groww" back in 2021. Initially, I was super scared, you know? Thinking I'd lose it all. I put it into a couple of "safe" blue-chip stocks, like HDFC and Reliance.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked if investing in the stock market is worth it. Well, from my experience, it's a definite "maybe," leaning towards "yes, but with caution." I started with a small amount, rupee five thousand, through a friend's recommendation on this app called "Groww" back in two thousand twenty one. Initially, I was super scared, you know? Thinking I'd lose it all. I put it into a couple of "safe" blue-chip stocks, like H-D-F-C and Reliance.

unnormalised: Then, last year, around 2023, I got a bit bolder. Read up on some articles, watched a few YouTube videos (be careful, though, lots of bogus advice out there!). I started dabbling in mutual funds, a SIP of Rs. 2000 per month. Some did well, others not so much. One particular investment in a small-cap fund promised high returns, something like 15% annually, but the market volatility gave me the jitters, almost lost Rs. 1500/- in just 2 weeks!
normalised: Then, last year, around two thousand twenty three, I got a bit bolder. Read up on some articles, watched a few YouTube videos (be careful, though, lots of bogus advice out there!). I started dabbling in mutual funds, a S-I-P of rupees two thousand per month. Some did well, others not so much. One particular investment in a small-cap fund promised high returns, something like fifteen percent annually, but the market volatility gave me the jitters, almost lost rupees one thousand five hundred in just two weeks!

unnormalised: So, is it worth it? I think so. I’ve made some gains, maybe around ₹10,000 overall. Not life-changing money, but a decent return. The key is to be informed, start small, and don't put all your eggs in one basket. Consider consulting with a financial advisor (SEBI registered), they often charge a fee, say ₹ 2000-₹5000, but might be worth the peace of mind! Also, remember this isn't financial advice, just sharing my personal experience, bhai!
